body:
It's a common misconception about LGPL that it forces you to use dynamic
linking if your
code is not under (L)GPL.

Read section 4 d) of LGPL v3.

In fact, what LGPL requires is the ability to replace the linked LGPL
library with a new one,
so as long as we provide the ability to do that, we can use static linking.

that's how you can use Qt on iOS, where you're not allowed to use 3rdparty
shared libraries.

with the ability to do external linking, producing the object files needed
to relink the LGPL
library is actually quite easy. We just need to clearly separate out the
code that needs to
be provided as source code to facilitate the relinking.
